Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my headset still around my neck, as my stepbrother and stepsister chatted excitedly about hiking this weekend. Mom glanced at me, her eyes hopeful, and I knew she wanted me to join in, to be part of the family, to say yes when they asked if I’d come along. My phone buzzed with a reminder: my scheduled break was almost over. As a telemarketer, I was supposed to stick to my break times, but today the call volume was light, and my supervisor had said we could be flexible. Still, I worried about missing a call or being seen as unreliable. My family’s laughter pulled at me, but so did the quiet pressure of my job. I wanted to be present, to show my step-siblings I cared, but I also didn’t want to risk my reputation at work. My heart thudded as I looked from my family to the clock, torn between the warmth of belonging and the responsibility of my job, unsure which expectation I should meet.
